newsitem.title: CHINA: HK MORTGAGE CORP READY IN NOVEMBER - LELAND SUN.
newsitem.headline: HK MORTGAGE CORP READY IN NOVEMBER - LELAND SUN.

text.p: The Hong Kong Mortgage Corporation (HKMC) will start operations by November, allowing banks to cut their exposure to the property market and helping to build an asset-backed securities market, chief operating officer Leland Sun said.
The HKMC will start buying mortages from banks in four months' time and the mortgages will be repackaged into bonds to be sold to institutions.
The corporation was setting up a mortgage monitoring system and risk management guidelines such as credit, pre-payment, interest and operational risk, Sun told Hong Kong newspapers.
The HKMC intends to issue bonds in the first quarter of 1998 to finance further purchases of mortgage portfolios.

Sun said the price that the corporation was willing to pay for mortgages had yet to be decided. "It will depend on market conditions," he said. "We may pay different prices to different banks with different mortgage portfolios," he said.
By 1999 the HKMC planned to buy and resell at least HK$15 billion (US$1.94 billion) in loans a year, he said.
The HKMC is owned by the government through the Exchange Fund and has an initial working capital of HK$1 billion which is being used to pay set-up costs and to fund its first purchases.
